text: Competent transcription initiation by RNA polymerase II in cell-free extracts from xeroderma pigmentosum groups B and D in an optimized RNA transcription assay .

The human autosomal recessive disease , xeroderma pigmentosum ( XP ) , can result from mutations in any one of seven genes , designated <extra_id_0> XPA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> through <extra_id_0> XPG <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Of these , the <extra_id_0> XPB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> XPD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes encode proteins that are subunits of a general transcription factor , TFIIH , involved in both nucleotide excision repair ( NER ) and initiation of mRNA transcription by RNA polymerase II .

In humans , mutation of the <extra_id_0> XPB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> XPD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene impairs NER , resulting in hyper - sensitivity to sunlight and greatly increased skin tumor formation .
However , no transcription deficiency has been demonstrated in either <extra_id_0> XP-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> XP-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

We have employed an optimized cell-free RNA transcription assay to analyze transcription activity of <extra_id_0> XP-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> XP-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Although the growth rate was normal , the <extra_id_0> XP-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> XP-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cells contained reduced amounts of TFIIH .

Extracts prepared from <extra_id_0> XP-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> XP-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> lymphoblastoid cells exhibited similar transcription activity from the adenovirus major late promoter when compared to that in extracts from normal cells .

Thus , we conclude that the <extra_id_0> XP-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> XP-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> lymphoblastoid cells do not have impaired RNA transcription activity .

We consider the possible consequences of the reduced cellular content of TFIIH for the clinical symptoms in <extra_id_0> XP-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> XP-D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> patients , and discuss a 'conditional phenotype ' that may involve an impairment of cellular function only under certain growth conditions .
